The learning outcomes of MCDS Program include designing, implementing, and evaluating analytic algorithms on sample datasets; explaining how a machine-learning model is developed for and evaluated on real world datasets; designing and executing experimental data collection and presenting resulting analyses using appropriate user experience (UX) techniques including interactive data visualizations; applying and customizing analytics, systems, and human-centered data science techniques to application-specific data science requirements and objectives; identifying tradeoffs among data science techniques (analytics, systems, and/or human-centered); survey, interpreting, and comparatively criticizing state of the art research talks and papers with emphasis on constructive improvements; organizing, executing, reporting on, and presenting a real world data science project in collaboration with other researchers/programmers.

The Graduate Student Assembly (GSA) represents and advocates for the diverse interests of all graduate students at Carnegie Mellon University. It improves the graduate student experience, passes legislation, allocates student activities funding, advocates for legislative action locally and in Washington D.C., and acts on behalf of all graduate student interests.

Carnegie Mellon University offers students the opportunity to take courses for credit through a cross-registration program. The Carnegie Mellon University transcript will include information on such courses as follows: Carnegie Mellon courses and courses taken through the university's cross-registration program will have grades recorded on the transcript and be factored into the QPA. All other courses will be recorded on this transcript indicating where the course was taken, but without grade. Such courses will not be considered for academic actions, honors or QPA calculations.

LTI Orientation (also known as The Immigration Course or The IC) is a 2-3 week series of lectures and talks provided by the Language Technology Institute at the beginning of each Fall semester. It helps students learn about the work done by CMU faculty, provides an opportunity for advisors to recruit new students, and introduces them to the broad range of research done at the LTI.

The Graduate Student Assembly (GSA) represents and advocates for the diverse interests of all graduate students at CMU. It is composed of representatives from different graduate programs and departments who work to improve the graduate student experience at various levels of the university. GSA passes legislation, allocates student activities funding, advocates for legislative action locally and in Washington D.C., and acts on behalf of all graduate student interests.

An equivalent graduate course previously completed at another institution may be permitted to satisfy one of the Ph.D. course requirements. The decision on whether a course may be transferred is made by the Ph.D. Program Director. Typically, the student will provide the Program Director with the syllabus of the external course, and the Program Director will use that and the student’s transcript to make the decision.

The Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) degree is a professional Master of Science degree offered by the Language Technologies Institute (LTI), a department in the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University. International Students Immigration status for students in F-1 and J-1 nonimmigrant status is tied to making normal progress toward completing degree requirements. Therefore, F-1 and J-1 students who are considering completing their degree requirements early, anticipating longer-than-standard completion, or moving from an undergraduate to a graduate student classification (integrated undergraduate-graduate study) should consult with their designated advisor in the Office of International Education (OIE) to ensure compliance with immigration regulations.

The mission of the Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University is to provide physical, digital, and programmatic access to ensure that students with disabilities have equal access to their educational experience. The office works to ensure that qualified individuals receive reasonable accommodations as guaranteed by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.

An LTI Ph.D. student who uses courses taken as a Master’s degree student (at Carnegie Mellon or elsewhere) toward their program requirements cannot use those same courses toward any other Master’s degree offered by the school. The LTI (like other SCS units) allows its Ph.D. students who have passed the requirements for an LTI Master’s degree to receive the master’s degree without any additional work. Any other sharing of coursework by an LTI student between more than one CMU degree (e.g., receiving an MLD Master’s degree that includes courses taken as an LTI Ph.D. student) must be explicitly approved by the LTI, on a case-by-case basis, in advance.

The learning outcomes of MCDS Program include designing, implementing, and evaluating analytic algorithms on sample datasets; explaining how a machine-learning model is developed for and evaluated on real world datasets; designing and executing experimental data collection and presenting resulting analyses using appropriate user experience (UX) techniques including interactive data visualizations; applying and customizing analytics, systems, and human-centered data science techniques to application-specific data science requirements and objectives; identifying tradeoffs among data science techniques (analytics, systems, and/or human-centered); survey, interpreting, and comparatively criticizing state of the art research talks and papers with emphasis on constructive improvements; organizing, executing, reporting on, and presenting a real world data science project in collaboration with other researchers/programmers.
